texts.shortText:
Sea fans are characterized by having a stiff inner skeleton made of a horn-like protein called gorgonin. This is covered by an often brightly-pigmented layer of living tissue from which small, retractable polyps emerge. Each polyp has 8 pinnate (feathery) tentacles.

This relatively small species forms dense, bushy colonies with thin cylindrical stems that branch in all directions (not forming a fan). It often grows in tangled clumps among other encrusting organisms, such as bryozoans, tube worms and tunicates. Stems bear knobs from which polyps emerge.

Colour very variable, with polyps often contrasting with stems. Stems red, yellow, white of pink and polyps white, yellow or red.
Colonies up to about 200 mm tall, branches about 2-4 mm wide.

Global: Endemic to South Africa.

Local/Regional: Table Bay to about East London.

Common on vertical faces and under overhangs or beneath boulders in low shore pools and to a depth of about 150 m. Commonly fed upon by the Coral nudibranch Phyllodesmium horridum, which can denude whole areas of colony of their polyps.
Use the tentacles to capture small planktonic organisms from the water column.

Colonies spread by budding new polyps from the tips and broken fragments can develop into new colonies if deposited in suitable habitats. Details of sexual reproduction are unknown for this species, but other sea fans have separate male and female colonies and release sperm and eggs into the water. These merge to form planktonic larvae which settle and grow into new colonies.
The low, bushy, colony form and thin knobbly stems are fairly characteristic.
